Message.Title: windows 8 and software compatibility
Message.Msg: Well, I thought windows 8 would work for me. I bought a laptop-tossed classic shell on it and tried to load up my quickbooks pro. Sorry, not compatible. Disgusted, I pulled my hard drive out of my other laptop and tossed it into this new laptop. Thank goodness for compatible drivers with my hardware for windows 7. It saved me 800.00 from upgrading Quickbooks. Oh, the version was 2011. only 13 is compatible with 8. MS, again, fix your OS. I shouldn't have to upgrade software that is only 2 yrs old. Stick it (windows 8) where the sun don't shine please.

Topic.Title: Google vs Bing

Message.Msg: Most researchers will read the first two or three pages of results or until finding the info they're looking for, whichever comes first, and then stop. No one reads through 8,460,000 results and most certainly no one will have the time nor inclination to read through 213,000,000 of them. The point is that the absolute number of returned results means absolutely nothing. All that matters is the search algorithms' ability to sort and present the returns in a way that is relevant and applicable to the search terms entered. I think that if you compare those first two or three pages between the two engines you will find only a few minor differences between the results returned. Searchers are looking for accuracy, efficacy and efficiency, not endless volumes of useless information to waste their time sorting through.

Message.Title: Who Has the Fairest Web Browser of Them All?
Message.Msg: Google it. You will find an amateurish video based on data from Microsoft's pet "source", NetApplications, claiming what everyone knows to be false, namely that IE is still in the lead. According to StatCounter, IE is down to about 31% usage share worldwide, about 6 percentage points behind Google's Chrome. The trend for IE has been very steadily downward for years.

Topic.Title: Woman who voted up to six times for Obama admits doing so but says no fraud

Message.Msg: I vote by mail. They send me a ballot. If I go to a polling place they won't let me vote unless I lost my ballot and do some paper work. I can turn in my vote by mail ballot at the poling place, but that is still one vote. Let's say they goof and allow me to vote at the polling place, which where I live I see as impossible, but let's say they do. My second ballot isn't going to be counted, because they already have the one I sent in. The registrar or whoever keeps track of votes will not count my vote twice. They aren't new at this and go tyhrough a lot of pains to make sure each person votes once in their own name.It is virtually impossible to vote twice. Now this person was accused of voting six times. This was not for herself, she is accused of voting for others. This kind of activity is not restricted to one party. If a tea party crowd could find ways to vote more times each, believe me they would do it. What does indicted mean? no answer huh. bozo brains on the right, same old same old

Message.Title: IDC: Android expanding tablet share at Apple's expense
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: 'In a press release IDC said: "Android-based tablets expanded their share of the market notably in 2012, and IDC expects that trend to continue in 2013. Android's (GOOG) share of the market is forecast to reach a peak of 48.8% in 2013 compared to 41.5% in IDC's previous forecast. Android's gains come at the expense of Apple's (AAPL) iOS, which is expected to slip from 51% of the market in 2012 to 46% in 2013. Longer term, both iOS and Android will eventually relinquish some market share to Windows (MSFT)-based tablets, with Windows 8 predicted to grow from 1% of the market in 2012 to 7.4% in 2017. IDC expects Windows RT growth to remain below 3% during the forecast period." ' __________________________________ Looking even farther ahead, it can be predicted that Android, or other versions of Linux, will move on to take over some of what's left of the laptop/desktop market. By then, Microsoft will be toothless, unable to defend its share of that market.

Message.Title: Size Matters: Android Tablets To Surge Past iPads In 2013, Research Says
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "New numbers suggest that Steve Jobs was definitely wrong to once think consumers would find smaller tablets useless. Researchers at IDC have just raised their forecast for the total number of tablet computer shipped this year to 190.0 million from 172.4 million, thanks largely to a surge of smaller, lower-priced tablet computers. “One in every two tablets shipped this quarter was below 8 inches in screen size,” said IDC analyst Jitesh Ubrani. “And in terms of shipments, we expect smaller tablets to continue growing in 2013 and beyond.” ... "The trend for cheaper devices in particular comes at the expense of Apple, they add, as less costly Android-based tablets expand their share of the market to 48.8%. They expect Apple’s share to slip to 46% in 2013 from 51% last year."
